author: SpooniestBard

text:
Ah, I remember this. I love this level. Touch Fuzzy, Get Dizzy. The title of the level had a simple, but effective warning. Despite this, I touched the fuzzies just to see Yoshi stagger around like a drunken lizard. I didn't know it back then, but the behavior and color changing Yoshi experiences when touching Fuzzies is actually just an acid trip.

And that, children, is why scientists are trying to turn dandelion spores into flying drugs.

text:
I agree, for a while i was convinced that it was nostalgia alone that made me like my childhood games more, but it's not the case.

i bought a snes a few months ago and played some of the old games (mainly earthbound, yoshi's island, chrono trigger, etc), and they really are better.

maybe it's because back then they knew the graphics they had were the best they could come up with, so they decided to make games with real content instead of pretty images.

text:
Well, suffice it to say, Nintendo's never been big on continuity.

At the same time, remember that the cartoon was an American cartoon. Nintendo really didn't have much to do with it.

Finally, if you want to get REALLY picky. Aren't Mario and Luigi supposed to have grown up in Brooklyn?

author: SilentBlade72

text: It's a prequel. A stork is delivering Baby Mario and Baby Luigi to their parents, but are interrupted by Kamek, Baby Bowser's err...babysitter, so to speak. Baby Luigi is kidnapped and the Yoshies find Baby Mario abandoned on the island. They journey to reunite the babies with their parents.
